column2: Title
column3: Does the paper suggest methods to quantify the completeness of requirements?
column5: Description

column2: A tool-based boilerplate technique to improve SRS quality: An evaluation
column5: Experts score the completeness of the software requirements in the SRS produced using the tool-based boilerplate technique on a 5-point Likert scale.

column2: AI-Enabled Automation for Completeness Checking of Privacy Policies
column5: The proportion of actual incompleteness issues correctly identified by the approach out of all issues identified.

column2: A Multi-solution Study on GDPR AI-enabled Completeness Checking of DPAs
column5: The proportion of correct predictions (both true positives and true negatives) among the total number of cases examined.

column2: An approach: SysML-based automated completeness evaluation of the system requirements specification
column4: Functional Requirements Refinement by Behavior Elements Metric (RR_FR)
column5: Evaluates the refinement of functional requirements by behavior elements.

column2: Analysing sanity of requirements for avionics systems
column5: A function that measures the similarity between edge evaluations in two Büchi automata

column2: Assessing requirements-related risks through probabilistic goals and obstacles
column5: The probability of a goal being satisfied given possible obstructions

column2: Completeness of Natural Language Requirements: A Comparative Study of User Stories and Feature Descriptions
column5: This metric calculates the ratio of frame elements (FEs) that actually appear in a requirement sentence to the total number of FEs that should be evoked by the verbs in the sentence.

column2: Challenging Incompleteness of Performance Requirements by Sentence Patterns
column5: Requirements are classified into three categories based on their completeness level.

column2: An empirical comparative evaluation of requirements engineering methods
column5: Quantifies the completeness of functional requirements relative to a reference model.

column2: Measuring complexity and completeness of KAOS goal models
column4: M1 - Percentage of leaf goals that have an associated agent
column5: This metric directly quantifies the completeness of the KAOS model in terms of agent assignments.

column2: A framework to evaluate complexity and completeness of KAOS goal models
column4: PLGWA (Percentage of Leaf Goals With an Agent)
column5: Percentage of leaf goals that have an associated agent in the model.

column2: Measuring and improving the completeness of natural language requirements
column5: Measures the completeness of concepts in the requirements specification compared to the input documents.

column2: An automatic tool for the analysis of natural language requirements
column5: Number of defective sentences divided by the total number of sentences

column2: Metrics for measuring complexity and completeness for social goal models
column5: Measures the percentage of goals that have means-end links

column2: Semantic-based requirements analysis and verification
column5: A ratio that quantifies the completeness of the requirements specification

column2: Towards Improved Network Security Requirements and Policy: Domain-Specific Completeness Analysis via Topic Modeling
column5: Percentage of words in a document attributed to each topic by LDA

column2: Yet another set of requirement metrics for software projects
column5: Measures the completeness of gathered requirements

column2: Forward engineering completeness for software by using requirements validation framework
column5: Measures the completeness of functional requirements attributes

column2: Use case patterns driven requirements engineering
column5: A percentage measure of how complete the requirements model is compared to the final set of requirements for the project.

column2: Automated requirements engineering: Use case patterns-driven approach
column5: Measures the percentage of use cases covered by the catalogue compared to the total use cases in the project

column2: USQA: A User Story Quality Analyzer prototype for supporting software engineering students
column5: A binary measure of completeness based on the presence of all three required components in a user story.

column2: HAZOP-based identification of events in use cases: An empirical study
column5: Measures how many events a reviewer identifies compared to the total number of distinct events identified by all reviewers

column2: Using domain ontology as domain knowledge for requirements elicitation
column5: Measures the ratio of unmapped ontological elements to the total number of ontological elements

column2: Enhancing domain knowledge for requirements elicitation with Web mining
column5: The ratio of correctly elicited requirements to the total number of correct requirements

column2: Assessment of high integrity software components for completeness, consistency, fault-tolerance, and reliability
column5: While not a direct metric of completeness, the paper uses the results of fault injection tests to indirectly measure the completeness of requirements

column2: Automatic recommendation to omitted steps in use case specification
column5: The ratio of correctly recommended steps to the total number of recommended steps

column2: Sense: A flow-down semantics-based requirements engineering framework
column5: Statistical analysis of validation checks in three categories: incompleteness, inconsistency, and system model deficiencies.

column2: Using Language Models for Enhancing the Completeness of Natural-Language Requirements
column5: Measures the proportion of BERT's predictions that match novel terminology in the withheld portion of requirements.

column2: Improving requirements completeness: automated assistance through large language models
column5: Ratio of terms in BERT predictions matching some term in the novel terminology of the withheld portion, to the total number of predicted terms.

column2: An experimental comparison regarding the completeness of functional requirements specifications
column5: Counts the number of system goals addressed in the requirements specification

column2: Automated requirements validation for ATP software via specification review and testing
column5: Percentage of statements in the prototype executed by test scenarios

column2: An intelligent recommender system based on association rule analysis for requirement engineering
column5: Ratio of the support of rule items to the support of rule head

column2: Using correctness, consistency, and completeness patterns for automated scenarios verification
column5: Measures the consistency of syntax and semantic rules used in scenario descriptions.

column2: Framework for measuring the quality of software specification
column5: A percentage-based metric that quantifies the completeness of the SRS structure based on the number of matched and additional topics compared to the IEEE 830 standard.

column2: Evaluation of software requirement specification based on IEEE 830 quality properties
column5: The percentage of topics in the SRS that match or are similar to the topics in the IEEE 830 standard table of contents.

column2: An AI-Assisted Approach for Checking the Completeness of Privacy Policies against GDPR
column5: The ratio of correctly identified incompleteness issues to the total number of identified issues

column2: A Meta-Requirement Approach to Validate User Requirement Specification: Threshold Definition
column5: STATE is a proposed unit of measurement used to quantify the completeness of requirements. It represents the percentage of User Requirements (URs) that successfully map to the Meta-Requirements (MR) graph pattern.

column2: PolicyChecker: Analyzing the GDPR Completeness of Mobile Apps' Privacy Policies
column5: The total number of unsatisfied mandatory requirements and unsatisfied if-applicable requirement logic chains in a privacy policy.

column2: aToucan: An automated framework to derive UML analysis models from use case models
column5: Measures the completeness of a class diagram based on missing classes, associations, and generalizations

column2: Automating scenario-driven structured requirements engineering
column5: Measures the adequacy of a set of test scenarios in covering the requirements model.

column2: On the interplay between consistency, completeness, and correctness in requirements evolution
column5: Ratio between size of maximal entailed subset and full specification
